Journal.Title: Journal of toxicology and environmental health. Part A

Article.ArticleTitle: Association between fine particulate air pollution and hospital admissions for chest pain in a subtropical city: Taipei, Taiwan.

AbstractText: This study determined the association between fine particles (PM<sub>2.5</sub>) levels and hospital admissions for chest pain (CP) in Taipei, Taiwan. Hospital admissions for CP and ambient air pollution data for Taipei were obtained for the period 2009-2013. The relative risk of hospital admissions was estimated using a case-crossover approach, after controlling for weather variables, day of the week, seasonality, and long-term time trends. For single-pollutant models (without adjustment for other pollutants), increased frequency of CP admissions was significantly associated with PM<sub>2.5</sub> levels on warm days (>23°C), with an interquartile range rise correlated with a 15% (95% confidence interval = 11-31%) elevation in number of CP admissions. In two-pollutant models, PM<sub>2.5</sub> remained significant after inclusion of each of the other four pollutants: sulfur dioxide (SO<sub>2</sub>), nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>), carbon monoxide (CO), and ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) on warm days. Generally, no marked associations were observed between PM<sub>2.5</sub> levels and risk of CP admissions on cool days in both single- and two-pollutant models. This study provides evidence that higher PM<sub>2.5</sub> concentrations enhance the risk of hospital admissions for CP on warm days.
